mortality attributed to
digestive system tumors, with more than 700,000 deaths reported worldwide
annually.  The progression and
treatment response of tumors depend not only
on the cancer cells themselves but more on the tumor immune microenvironment
(TIME) in which they are located. The advancement of computer and
sequencing technologies in recent years has led to a new era of development
in immunology. Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) technology,
which allows for the detection of gene expression at the cellular
level, has become a powerful tool in immunology research. scRNA-seq
technology is revolutionary in its ability to analyze the genome,
transcriptome, and epigenome at the level of individual cells. Single-cell
sequencing technology has revolutionized our understanding of the
gene expression profiles associated with diseases. It offers unique
advantages in elucidating the heterogeneity of hybrid tumor cells
comprising cancer cells, stromal cells, immune cells, and various
differentiated cells.  Among
the various cells in the tumor immune microenvironment (TIME),
tumor-associated neutrophils have been found in recent years to play
complex and crucial roles in tumor progression, immune escape, and
treatment resistance. However, their specific roles in gastric cancer
still need to be further explored. Neutrophils are highly abundant
immune granulocytes with crucial functions in acute and chronic inflammation
as well as adaptive immune responses. These cells are frequently found
in the tumor immune microenvironment of cancer, and their role in
tumorigenesis and development has been increasingly studied and better
understood in recent years. According to research, cytokines and chemical
signals within the tumor immune microenvironment can polarize neutrophils
into different roles, influencing tumor progression. Specifically,
neutrophils can transform into N1 tumor-associated neutrophils with
antitumor effects through IFN-β, IL-1β, and IL-8. Alternatively,
they can become N2 tumor-associated neutrophils that promote tumor
progression, induced by TGF-β, GM-CSF, and IL-6.   The identification of tumor
microenvironments containing various
cell subtypes is a crucial application of single-cell sequencing,
which also promotes the progress of tumor-targeted therapy and immunotherapy.
Nonetheless, research on neutrophils within the tumor immune microenvironment
remains relatively scarce. Given this advantage, this study is based
on single-cell sequencing data of liver metastases from gastric cancer,
reveals the molecular characteristics of TANs in metastatic gastric
cancer, and accordingly develops and validates a novel prognostic
risk score, namely the NE-riskScore. This study utilized single-cell
sequencing data from liver metastases of gastric cancer to investigate
the potential of tumor-associated neutrophils in immune typing, prognostic
prediction, therapeutic efficacy guidance, and drug prediction for
gastric cancer. Materials and Methods Data Acquisition and Processing Obtaining the single-cell
transcriptome profile of gastric cancer involved downloading the GSE163558 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ https://portal.gdc.cancer.gov/repository https://www.gtexportal.org/ GSE26842 GSE84437 Construction of Protein–Protein Interaction (PPI) Network The PPI network analysis was performed using the STRING database
( https://string-db.org/ Identification of Immune-Related Molecular Subtypes We used the “NMF” R package to cluster samples based
on prognostic genes and evaluated the clustering performance for numbers
ranging from 2 to 10. The prognostic performance of different molecular
subtypes was assessed using Kaplan–Meier curves for progression-free
survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS). To estimate ImmuneScore,
StromalScore, EstimateScore, and tumor purity for each sample, we
employed the “estimate” R package and visualized the
results using the “ggpubr” R package. We analyzed the
immune cell infiltration compositions of different samples using the
MCPcounter software. Additionally, we performed multiple GSEA analyses
to compare the pathway enrichment differences between the two immune
molecular subtypes. Construction and Validation of Prognostic Risk Models The gastric cancer patient samples were randomly split into equally
sized training and test groups. Neutrophil-associated signatures linked
to prognosis were constructed using training data and were internally
validated using test data. To identify survival-associated genes,
we performed univariate Cox regression analysis at a significance
level of p GSE26842 GSE84437 Construction of Nomogram and Clinical Correlation Analysis of
Risk Score Using the rms R package, we constructed a nomogram
for 1-year, 2-year, and 3-year overall survival (OS) by incorporating
the risk score, age, and tumor stage. We assessed the accuracy of
the predicted results using a calibration curve to evaluate the agreement
between the predicted and actual outcomes. We further classified GC
patients according to age (≤65/>65), gender (male/female),
and clinical stage (I-II/III-IV). Additional verification of the predictive
ability of NE-riskScore across different subgroups was performed using
survival analysis. We compared pathway enrichment between different
risk groups using the R package “GSEA” and enrichment
data (c2.cp.kegg.v7.4.symbols.gmt). Analysis of Tumor Mutation Burden (TMB) and Immune Relevance Somatic mutant profiles of GC patients in both high- and low-risk
groups were obtained from the TCGA database using the “maftools”
software package. The immune cell infiltration status of TCGA GC patients
was determined through multiple methods, including TIMER, CIBERSORT,
QUANTISEQ, XCELL, MCPcounter, and EPIC, as provided by TIMER2.0 ( http://timer.cistrome.org/ http://tide.dfci.harvard.edu/ Prognostic Gene Expression Analysis We utilized the
Tumor Immune Single-cell Hub (TISCH) database ( http://tisch.comp-genomics.org www.proteinatlas.org/ Patient Sample Clinical and pathological data from
40 patients with advanced gastric cancer who underwent radical surgery
and received treatment at Jiangsu University Affiliated People’s
Hospital between July 2020 and September 2024 were retrospectively
analyzed. Based on their initial evaluation of the efficacy of treatment
with the drug camrelizumab, the patients were categorized into two
groups based on their response: the good response group and the poor
response group. Tumor initial evaluation referred to the efficacy
evaluation conducted two months after the start of routine treatment
combined with camrelizumab immunotherapy. All 40 patients with gastric
cancer were detected as MSS/pMMR, and imaging examinations showed
at least one objectively measurable or evaluable tumor lesion. The
response to treatment was evaluated using the Response Evaluation
Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST), which is a standard method for
assessing the efficacy of treatments for solid tumors. Complete response
(CR) refers to the disappearance of all lesions lasting for 4 weeks
or more; partial response (PR) indicates a reduction of at least 30%
in the total diameter of the target lesion lasting for 4 weeks or
more, based on the baseline total diameter as the reference; progressive
disease (PD) indicates an increase of at least 20% in the total diameter
of the target lesion compared to its smallest sum in the study, or
the appearance of new lesions; stable disease (SD) refers to cases
where the target lesion was neither reduced to PR nor increased to
PD. Among the patients, 20 were in the good response group (CR + PR),
and 20 were in the poor response group (SD + PD). Samples of both
tumor and adjacent nontumor tissue were obtained from all 40 gastric
cancer patients. The Medical Ethics Committee of Jiangsu University
Affiliated People’s Hospital approved the study protocol, and
all participants provided written informed consent. Quantitative Real-Time PCR (qRT-PCR) Standard protocols
were followed to extract total RNA from GC tissues using Trizol reagent
(Solarbio, Beijing, China). Following the RNA extraction, reverse
transcription was performed using the PrimeScript RT kit and gDNA
Eraser (TaKaRa, Otsu, Japan). qRT-PCR based on SYBR Green was used
for the analysis. The expression level was calculated by 2 –ΔΔCt Table S1 Drug Sensitivity Analysis and Molecular Docking The
OncoPredictR package was used to evaluate drug sensitivity, and then
comparative analysis was performed using the Wilcoxon signed-rank
test. To identify potential therapeutic small molecules, we retrieved
a list of compounds that interact with prognostic genes from the CTD
database ( http://ctdbase.org/ https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ https://www.uniprot.org Statistical Analysis We performed statistical analysis
using R software (V4.1.1) and GraphPad Prism 9.4.1 (GraphPad Software,
USA). The Wilcoxon test was used to compare gene expression levels
between the tumor and normal tissues. A p-value of less than 0.05
was deemed statistically significant unless otherwise specified. Result Data Processing and Cell Cluster Identification The GSE163558 Figure S1A R R Figure S1B Figure Figure S1C Figure Figure Figure S1D Figure Figure Figure Table S2 1 Single-cell
data analysis and cell cluster identification: (A)
Scatter map of differential genes. (B) 20 PCS with significant differences.
(C) Dimensionality reduction and clustering visualized using the tSNE
algorithm, identifying 15 distinct cell clusters. (D) Cell type annotation
of the 15 clusters, identifying 5 major immune cell types. (E) The
most prominent marker genes of the five types of immune cells. (F)
Pseudotime and trajectory analysis. Enrichment Analysis and Construction of PPI Network We obtained transcriptome expression profiles from multiple sources
to conduct our analysis. Specifically, we retrieved data on 375 gastric
cancer tissues and 32 normal gastric tissues from the TCGA database,
as well as an additional 174 normal gastric tissues from the GTEx
database. Using batch integration analysis, we integrated and compared
the data sets. 371 genes exhibited differential expression among the
553 neutrophil marker genes in gastric cancer tissues, as revealed
by the differential expression analysis ( Figure Figure Figure Figure Figure 2 Enrichment analysis and construction of
the protein interaction
network of differential genes: (A) Differential gene expression heatmap.
(B) Bar and circular diagrams of GO enrichment analysis. (C) Bar and
circular diagrams of KEGG enrichment analysis. (D) The PPI network
was visualized, with upregulated expression shown in red and downregulated
expression in green. (E) Subnetwork of proteins related to the six
genes used to construct the NE-riskScore. Immunophenotyping and Analysis of Immune Microenvironment To investigate whether the neutrophil-derived gene set could stratify
patients into subtypes with distinct immune microenvironments, a characteristic
we intended to subsequently represent using a continuous NE-riskScore,
we performed non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) clustering. Molecular
clustering analysis was conducted in gastric cancer patients. We identified
two molecular subtypes comprising all GC samples under the clustering
threshold of maxK = 10 ( Figures S2 and S3 Figure Figure Figure Figure Figure  Figure 3 Molecular subtyping
and immune microenvironment analysis: (A) Consensus
matrix of NMF clustering results. (B,C) Kaplan–Meier analysis
(OS and PFS) of the two molecular subtypes. (D) The molecular subtypes
exhibited differences in immune cell infiltration. (E) Tumor immune
microenvironment scores (matrix score, immune score, ESTIMATE score,
and tumor purity score) of the two molecular subtypes. (F) Immune
checkpoint genes exhibit differential expression between the two molecular
subtypes. (G) Multiple GSEA pathway enrichment analysis. (* p p p Construction, Validation, and Prognostic Value of NE-riskScore A relevant risk model was constructed by using the identified differentially
expressed marker genes. The patients were randomly divided into two
groups, namely, the training and test groups, where the training group
was used for building the prognostic model and the test group was
used for validation. Clinical statistical analysis of the grouping
verified that there was no clinical characteristic bias between the
groups, demonstrating the rationality of the grouping ( Table S3 Figure Table Figure 4 Construction and verification of NE-riskScore: (A) LASSO regression
analysis identified six prognostic genes. (B) Kaplan–Meier
curves of six prognostic genes. (C) Kaplan–Meier curves of
overall survival (OS) time in the general population, training group,
test group, and GEO external cohort. (D) ROC curves of 1-, 3-, and
5-year survival rates in the general population, training group, and
test group. (E) The clinical features and risk scores in patients
with gastric cancer were analyzed by using univariate and multivariate
Cox regression. (F) The NE-riskScore was compared with five other
prognostic risk models for gastric cancer in the literature by examining
their respective ROC curves for predicting the 1-, 3-, and 5-year
survival rates. (G) Comparison of the C-index. (H) A nomogram was
utilized to predict the survival rates of gastric cancer patients
at 1, 3, and 5 years. (I) Calibration curve. 1 Correlation Coefficients of 6 NEG id coef CDA 0.178258571791622 MARCKS 0.380766378460764 IL17RA –0.752643432946746 DDX24 0.604387652476984 TOMM20 0.485854508678431 LBH 0.396626969736685 To investigate whether the constructed NE-riskScore
has a significant
prognostic value, we downloaded matrix data and survival data from
the GSE26842 GSE84437 Figure S4A Figure Figure Figure  Figure To provide more accurate personalized predictions
for gastric cancer
patients, we constructed a nomogram that includes risk scores and
clinical pathological features. The nomogram is capable of predicting
survival rates over 1, 3, and 5 years ( Figure Figure Figure S4B Analysis of Gene Mutation and Immune Correlation between High-
and Low-Risk Groups To explore a potential mechanism (genomic
instability) that might explain the different immune responses observed
among the NE-riskScore groups, we compared the tumor mutation burden.
To analyze somatic mutations in the STAD data set of the TCGA database
and compare them between two distinct risk groups, we used waterfall
diagrams ( Figure Figure Figure  Figure Figure Figure Figure n n Figure 5 Molecular subtyping and
analysis of the immune microenvironment:
(A) Waterfall plot depicting somatic mutations in the high- and low-risk
groups. (B) Differences in tumor mutational burden. (C,D) Differences
in immune escape score and MSI status. (E) Variations in immune cell
infiltration were observed between the high- and low-risk groups.
(F) IPS scores in high- and low-risk groups. (G) GSEA enrichment analysis
in high- and low-risk groups. (H) The difference in risk scores between
patients with good and poor responses to immunotherapy (* p p p Analysis and Validation of 6 Prognostic-Related Genes Based on the analysis of GSE134520 Figure Figure Figure 6 Analysis and validation of prognosis-related gene expression: (A)
Analysis of the GSE134520 p p p Drug Sensitivity Analysis and Molecular Docking of Prognostic
Genes We examined the relationship between the risk score
of GC patients and the sensitivity of targeted and chemotherapeutic
drugs to further compare the differences in potential drug sensitivity
between the high- and low-risk groups. The analysis revealed that
the low-risk group had greater sensitivity to 12 commonly used chemotherapeutic
drugs, including 5-fluorouracil, camptothecin, cisplatin, cytarabine,
docetaxel, epirubicin, gemcitabine, irinotecan, oxaliplatin, paclitaxel,
vinblastine, and vincristine. Additionally, 9 targeted drugs, such
as afatinib, afuresertib, axitinib, dabrafenib, erlotinib, gefitinib,
sorafenib, and trametinib, were more sensitive in the low-risk group
compared to the high-risk group, except for dasatinib, which demonstrated
greater sensitivity in the latter ( Figure S5  Figure Figure Figure Figure Figure Figure 7 Molecular docking of
drugs: (A) Docking result of tamoxifen with
CDA. (B) Docking result of ICG-001 with DDX24. (C) Docking result
of doxorubicin with IL17RA. (D) Docking result of irinotecan with
LBH. (E) Docking result of doxorubicin with MARCKS. (F) Docking result
of doxorubicin with TOMM20. Discussion Gastric cancer is a major contributor to
global cancer-related
mortality. The current treatment modalities for this disease consist
of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. However, these therapies
have limited efficacy and may cause significant side effects. In the
field of gastric cancer treatment, molecular subtyping, immunotherapy,
and precision medicine have become increasingly popular in recent
years. Currently, the molecular subtyping biomarkers that are clinically
used in gastric cancer mainly include HER2, PD-L1, mismatch repair
protein deficiency (dMMR), microsatellite instability (MSI), and tumor
mutational burden (TMB).  The present study involved
the analysis of scRNA-seq data from
patients diagnosed with metastatic gastric cancer. Through quality
control and dimensionality reduction clustering, we obtained marker
genes of immune cell types that infiltrated the tumor tissue. To investigate
the role of neutrophils in the tumor immune microenvironment, we conducted
functional enrichment analysis and constructed interaction networks
based on the marker genes associated with neutrophils. Following the
analysis of differentially expressed genes, we conducted NMF molecular
subtyping of the samples and observed that patients in C2 exhibited
superior OS and PFS compared with those in C1. After additional analysis
of the tumor immune microenvironment, it was found that patients in
C1 exhibited elevated levels of immune cell infiltration, immune scores,
and immune checkpoint expression compared with those in C2. A risk
score model based on six prognosis-related genes was developed and
validated in this study. Compared with previous studies, the innovation
of this model lies in its clear cell origin (directly derived from
the scRNA-seq data of TANs), which avoids the noise caused by bulk
data decomposition and improves its accuracy and reliability. Therefore,
this model accurately distinguishes between high-risk and low-risk
groups, predicts prognosis, and exhibits superior performance compared
to the other five models. The low-risk group showed longer overall
survival compared to the high-risk group in the training, testing,
entire, and external validation cohorts. Furthermore, the risk score
was identified as an independent prognostic factor for patients. To
improve the practicality of the risk model in clinical settings, we
created a nomogram for assessing the 1-, 3-, and 5-year survival rates
of patients. The low-risk group demonstrated enrichment in metabolic
pathways, such as DNA replication, carbohydrate metabolism, and peroxisomes,
as indicated by GSEA analysis. Conversely, the high-risk group was
enriched in cell signaling pathways, such as ECM receptor interaction
and neuroactive ligand–receptor interaction. Additional immune
analysis demonstrated that the low-risk group had elevated levels
of infiltration of diverse immune cells including T cells, B cells,
and neutrophils. This group also exhibited increased tumor mutation
burden and higher sensitivity to immune therapy in contrast to the
high-risk group. After validation of this idea in 40 MSS/pMMR gastric
cancer patients, it is apparent that the risk score model has the
potential to predict the efficacy of immune therapy. In addition,
the evaluation of drug sensitivity in high- and low-risk
groups uncovered variations in the reaction to 22 prevalent chemotherapy
and targeted medications, thus presenting novel perspectives for treatment
selection according to the risk model. The difference in sensitivity
to chemotherapy and targeted drugs between the high- and low-risk
groups provides a theoretical basis for “individualized chemotherapy”.
Additionally, we employed molecular docking to identify four small-molecule
compounds (tamoxifen, ICG-001, irinotecan, and doxorubicin) that have
the potential to ameliorate the negative prognosis associated with
prognostic genes, thus presenting new avenues for targeted therapy
in GC. Significant associations between six risk markers and the prognosis
of gastric cancer patients were identified ( Figure  This study,
based on single-cell transcriptomics, has made new
breakthroughs in predicting prognosis, exploring immunotherapy, and
drug discovery related to tumor-associated neutrophils. However, there
are still limitations to this study. To validate our conclusions,
larger-scale and multicenter clinical data are still required. In
addition, further elucidation of molecular mechanisms is needed for
new prognostic molecular markers. Conclusions In this study, we provided a comprehensive
description of the precise
application of neutrophils in the immune microenvironment of metastatic
gastric cancer cells for survival prediction and immune therapy in
patients based on single-gene transcriptomics. We developed a robust
prognostic model derived from TANs, namely, the NE-riskScore. It is
not only a powerful prognostic prediction tool but also a comprehensive
indicator that can reflect the status of the tumor immune microenvironment,
predict the response to immunotherapy, and guide drug selection, providing
new perspectives and strategies for precision medicine in gastric
cancer. In addition, we used virtual molecular docking to screen four
small-molecule drugs targeting prognostic genes, which brings new
insights into targeted therapy. Supplementary Material The authors express their sincere gratitude
to the
reviewers for their valuable comments on this article, as well as
to the research groups who generously provided the data for this collection
from the TCGA, GTEx, and CEO. The data are
available throughout the manuscript and additional file. The Supporting Information is
